userreviews.userReview: Jacinta is one of my new favorite characters. Her story rang true to the plight of many pre-teen girls-- conflicting emotions about growing up, the desire to be good at something and fit in, the feeling of both loving and hating your parents at the same time, et al. But Jacinta must also deal with the anger, fear, and confusion of being the American-born daughter of undocumented Mexican immigrants. Young readers will love Jacinta’s tenacity and be able to both identify with and learn from her important story.
A great read—and one that shows a lot of honesty and authenticity on both the part of the narrator and the window we get into her mentor.

I bought this book after hearing the author read the opening pages. The voice caught me immediately - clear, charming, and authentic. But when I sat down to read, I discovered a story that was so much more. A girl child whose world is too small. She chooses to crash through those confining walls for entirely the "wrong" reasons. Jacinta is feisty and argumentative, jealous and scared and lonely, wrestling her way through the tangles, sorrows, and hard truths of the life she was born to. But through the year of her relationship with "Miss," she discovers her own voice, her own strengths, and the strength, weaknesses, and humanity of those around her. Never predictable, this story is both heart wrenching and a joy.

I had my doubts starting this one, but Judith Robbins Rose approaches the subject in a real and responsible way. She doesn't force a white savior complex, but instead illustrates the effects of one life on another. It's also filled with gems of wisdom that are digestible to younger students. I look forward to sharing this book with a focus group of students to see their thoughts on the text.

This book is about a girl named Jacinta Juarez who is struggling with the absence of her mother and is paired with a rich, famous mentor. This book tells a story about the struggle of a young girl trying to stay true to her roots and at the same time wants to fulfill a better future. As Jacinta’s world expands, so does her confusion about where she belongs. I really liked this book because I believe many students who come from immigrant families can relate to this story. It is hard for students to stay true to their roots when being in a country where culture and values are different. People have to adjust to their new homes and fit into society"Look Both Ways in the Barrio Blanco" is a realistic fictions story. I believe this is an interesting book for children that offers a variety of things to think about.

Jacinta and her two sisters were born in the United States but her parents are undocumented workers. When her parents are deported Jacinta must rely on her mentor for help. A heartrending story that depicts the tragedy of deportation and the consequences that are forced on the children.

So glad I got to see the world through Jacinta's eyes. This book is an honest and complex yet heartfelt take on how it feels to walk "la línea;" to have one foot in your parents' heritage and one in "the country where [you] were born and educated." Wonderful story.
Absolutely incredible. I don't care who you are, read this book. 100% worth your time.
Great voice and topic!

Jacinta, the protagonist of Look Both Ways in the Barrio Blanco, is a Mexican-American girl struggling with the otherness that her conflicted nationality imparts on her life and identity. Her tenuous family life tells a story of the Mexican diaspora experience in the United States, one that seems ubiquitous but also very particularly situated. Just as her mother, battered and desperate, crosses "la linea" in a attempt to return home to a crumbling family, Jacinta's father is arrested and presumably deported. While depression sinks in at the loss of her father, and the mistreatment he endures as an illegal immigrant, Jacinta is confronted with her own responsibilities and privileges in the face of the internal polarities her shared identity creates. Her sister, Rosa, is awakened even further to their otherness as Mexican-American U.S. citizens when she returns there for Abuelita's funeral, as she is told that she and her family are rich Americans who are obligated to send money back to their impoverished extended family. In dialogue, Jacinta is shocked to think that she is neither Mexican, nor American. Rosa begins, stating, "We are not Mexicans." After Jacinta responds with a disbelieving, "You're lying...We're not rich!," Rosa reminds her, "We are not Americans." "W-where do we belong?," asks Jacinta. The truth of this crushes her, of being neither and certaintly not both, echoing in the now hollow spaces her unreconciled polarity.So it is from the untethered, tenuous space of an unhinged self that Jacinta is envious, resentful, and aggressive. She is ungrateful of the mutually self-serving relationship she covets with Miss, the Amiga whom she clings to and loathes. Miss is equally manipulative, taking Jacinta on in a mentor/mentee relationship out of guilt and an obligation to "save" the little girl she exploited in her micro-aggressive news stories. While Miss wields her privilege and power as a white American and local celebrity to provide Jacinta and her sister with unrecognizable opportunities, the risks she takes and the losses she faces continuously translate into condescending assimilationism. Jacinta understands intuitively, narrating, "I wanted to tell Angelica that rich white ladies become Amigas to make themselves feel good, not because they care about us. I wanted to tell her that they aren't really brave or strong. They just seem that way, because there's nothing in their world to be afraid of" (240). Indeed, her profound insight proves both reactive and reflective when taken in consideration with the ways she herself is perceived by her uncles in Mexico. Fear and loss, it seems here, are begrudgingly relative and insidiously universal, though not universalized.As for Jacinta and her apparent lack of grace and gratitude, I think it is from the most underprivileged, oppressed populations that we expect the most of those challenging qualities. Are we concerned about Miss's gratitude for Jacinta in making her "soft" story on teen pregnancy, for which the child was neither? What educational opportunities did the mentor squander and waste, while Jacinta was expected to show humble desperation while crumbs of a better life sprinkled all around her, in mock service to making this country a safe place for all to live comfortably in the potential multiplicity of one's identities? Might it be that in her marked rejection of that biased expectation to perform gratefully as the "other" that resistance, resilience, and subversion occur most profoundly? If this is true, than Jacinta stands as a hero of democracy at its most crucial time.
Good to read this from the children's point of view. Our immigration policy has a real consequences far beyond what most of us think.

E ARC from Netgalley.comJacinta meets newswoman Kate Dawson Dahl at her community center. Jacinta is working on a picture frame for a Mother's Day gift, and Kate is reporting on teen pregnancy. When Kate accidentally ruins Jacinta's project, she feels bad about it, and Jacinta is quick to jump on this and ask if Kate (or "Miss", as she calls her) will be her Amiga, a sort of Big Sister mentor. Kate, a struggling single mother of two boys Jacinta's age, doesn't want to get involved, but is soon taking Jacinta to the local rec center to swim, and signing her up for gymnastics and French programs. Jacinta's home life is not good-- her mother has gone back to Mexico to care for her dying mother, and the family doesn't know when she will be back. Jacinta and her older sister, Rosa, must care for their baby sister Suelita with the help of their Tia. Tia has her own problems-- the father of her three children is a drunk, and is soon deported. While Jacinta is plotting to visit Kate's house, befriend her boys, and see if Miss will buy her things, she also has to deal with her father being deported and the family being evicted from their apartment. For a while, Jacinta is angry with Kate because she asks the girls to live with her, and Jacinta is jealous of Rosa, but when Jacinta's mother calls from New Mexico, where she has made it over the border with a coyote who has stolen her money, Jacinta calls Kate for help once again. Strengths: It's good to see a book that addresses the not-so-subtle change between being in one neighborhood and another in a fairly small town, and the differences between trying to scratch out an existence as an illegal immigrant or as a single mother. Like Gaby, Lost and Found, this portrays a family in an impossible situation, and there are no easy answers. The cover art reminds me very strongly of stories about Hispanic Americans in the reading textbooks we had in the 1970s, somehow.Weaknesses: Jacinta is not nice at all. Yes, her situation is difficult, but she mistreats everyone around her, including her sister, whom she hits in the face and scars! Kate ends up losing her job and having a lot of horrible things happen to her because she mentored Jacinta. Not sure what message this is meant to send!What I really think: I will probably buy this. Students like detestable characters more than I do, and I have a large number of Hispanic students and not enough books that reflect the variety of experiences in the US. I have one girl especially who is always asking for more books, and she will be glad to get this.

Through a series of haphazard incidents, middle-schooler Jacinta manages to weasel her way into the heart of adult news anchor, Kate, who reluctantly becomes her mentor. Jacinta's family is in the country illegally. Her father works all the time and her mother is back in Mexico caring for her sick grandmother. This means Jacinta and her older sister often spend hours alone caring for their younger sibling. Keeping this information from mentor Kate is difficult, especially when Jacinta's father does not return after work one night. This book had a powerful affect on me, an affect that is undoubtedly influenced by my very white life in my very white neighborhood, teaching in a school of predominately Hispanic students, many of whom are illegal immigrants. As I read the book, the stories of my students echoed back from the pages, and I felt like this book might be one with which they could really relate.Then I heard from an adult Hispanic reader that this book was a terrible representation of her culture and she would hate to have children read this story and think this was how they were portrayed in literature. She did not like the character of Jacinta, who admittedly was self-absorbed and a bit obnoxious. I, however, found Jacinta's innner dialogue and turmoil to be indicative of the real feelings middle school children have as they begin to realize that the world is bigger than themselves. She also didn't appreciate the implications that Jacinta's older sister might be tempted to engage in activities that may lead her to an early pregnancy, also a situation that rang true in the stories I hear. My feelings about this book have not changed. I believe it is important to read and hear the stories of children who are in the country illegally, to understand and empathize with their fear and confusion. And I definitely want kids to read these stories too. I think it is an important book, especially in this day and age. But that's just coming from me, and my opinion might not matter as much as others.

So moving! Do not let the reading level/recommended age fool you. This is a realistic book about culture clash. I am recommending this book to adults. If you desire any sense of what the Mexican immigration experience feels like from the point of view of the children, this is the perfect book for you. This is told in the first person voice of Jacinta. Through a chain of circumstances, a famous white woman becomes her mentor. How they misjudge each other and how they determine what is really important make for a beautiful story. Both of these individuals are enriched by learning from one another. (I love how Jacinta becomes fluent in FRENCH!) Jacinta's dialogue is snapping, angry, tense. It is perfect for the stressful situations she finds herself in. Also, she is still an immature 12 year old girl despite being called on to be an adult far too often! Interwoven in the book are terrific vocabulary words as Jacinta increases her exposure to English. This is a debut novel. Congratulations to the author! Wow! This has heart and levels of understanding that are conveyed in amazing scenes.

I gave this book four stars because I really enjoyed it. I read a few other reviews before beginning this book. Although I agree that in some ways Jacinta is not a very sympathetic character, in most ways she is a typical twelve year old who has had quite a few challenges in her life and is doing the best she can. She experiences a lot of growth throughout the book, and in the end I really was cheering for her.I had to trust that the author is giving us an accurate portrayal of what life might be like for a kid in Jacinta's position. I recently tried to read Hour of the Bees and was disappointed to find that the author did not seem to do a good job of portraying a young girl from Albuquerque, or the setting she chose. Rose's author blurb on the jacket would indicate she has worked with disadvantaged girls and is familiar with the region she set her book. I would love to read a book told from Rosa's POV. Just sayin'.

Jacinta and her sisters were born in Colorado, but her parents are not in this country legally. Her mother has returned to Mexico to take care of their abuelita, who is very sick. Jacinta knows that she has to be careful with what she says and how she acts, so that she does not bring the attention of the authorities to her family. The fear of deportation is a real and constant threat. When a local news broadcaster shows up at the after school youth center, Jacinta latches on to her. Part jealousy of her best friend's mentor and part desperate longing for her own mother, Jacinta finds ways to bring Miss (as she calls her) more into her life. As she lies to both her family and Miss, Jacinta finds herself caught between the world she grew up in and the world of white Americans, in a precarious balancing act that could spell disaster for her family. Recommended for grades 4 & up.

Jacinta Juárez struggles with situations and decisions which put her at odds with herself, her family and her environment. Can she make her way in the barrio blanco (white neighborhood) while still respecting her family’s rules and her Mexican heritage? When her parents need her help will she be able to cross la línea she has created inside herself to be there for her parents and family? Thanks to the help of her amiga Kate, and the educational experiences she and Jacinta have shared, Jacinta may be ready to face her biggest challenge. Jacinta’s story gives readers a peak at the life of Mexican immigrants, specifically American-born children of undocumented immigrants; their thoughts about money and white people and their fear of authority (gov’t and police) and deportation. This book would be a great addition to a school or public library. Recommended for grades 4-6.

Mexican-American Jacinta straddles two worlds - the fragile family existence with her undocumented parents, and the apparent advantages of the barrio blanco through her new Amiga, Kathryn Dawson Dahl. The author does a good job of capturing the instability, but also the tight-knitted community, of the immigrant families, and doesn't shy away from showing the unthinking exertion of white privilege. It would have been nice if the girl on the otherwise appealing cover could have looked more Mexican. See my full review here.

I read this book to my students. I was not a huge fan of it. There were good topics in it: immigration, racism, prejudices, and middle school drama. However, it was not a good depiction of Mexico--made it out to be a terrible place, no place anyone would want to return to--and the main character, Jacinta, was so whiny and ungrateful that my students thought she was obnoxious (I did too). The author also uses the same adjectives and metaphors throughout the book. It gets old. I would not recommend someone read this with a class, nor would I recommend it for pleasure. There is hope in themes, but it begs for better delivery.

Told from the point of view of an 11 year old Mexican-American, this story provides insight into the worlds of both an underprivileged child and the mentor who attempts to help her out. It demonstrates how even the best intentions can go awry without warning. I enjoyed how much the author emphasized the power of words, both in English and Spanish. Using her new-found power of words, the protagonist, Jacinta, explores many different aspects of a world outside of her little one in this story. By the end she is saying "I can walk la linea - the line between her world and that of my people." (336)This is a strong debut.

Jacinta and her family live in Colorado. Although Jacinta and her two sisters were all born in the USA and are legal citizens, Mama and Papi are not. They are always in danger of deportation and even though Jacinta is growing up in the United States, sometimes her life feels like a different world from the kids around her. She meets a local newswoman by chance and the two start a friendship that teaches both of them lots of unexpected lessons. Terrific story about the American immigrant experience and what it means for kids of immigrants. Strong female characters abound! Timely and a great read!

Jacinta Juarez's parents are in the US illegally and their status effects everything. Jacinta and her older sister Rosa must be careful who they talk to and how much information they give out. Papi is working two jobs while Mama has returned to Mexico to care for Abuelita. This leaves Rosa and Jacinta to care for baby Suelita. Things change for Jacinta when she convinces a well-known tv anchor to be her Amiga, read mentor, but the changes bring danger and fear to the family and her mentor in ways that no one could anticipate.
This was a good book. My full review is at http://bookreviewsandwallpapers.blogs...I received this book from Goodreads for an honest review
Problematic.
I was delightfully surprised by this book. It was funny And serious about what it would be like to be an illegal immigrant in the United States.

This is mostly a white people feel good book, kind of similar to The Help.First of all, it is necessary to recognize the striking similarities between the author, Judith Robbins Rose, and her character Kathryn Dawson Dahl. In case you missed the clear parallels, their names have almost identical alliteration patterns and have the exact same amount of syllables in each name. Also, JRR has a B.A. in Broadcast Journalism, while KDD’s character is a broadcast journalist. I had a hard time trying to figure out why Kathryn Dawson Dahl did anything for Jacinta's family. I kept wanting her to do something out of love and kindness, but it seemed like most of her actions were out of guilt and obligation. It was guilt that inspired her to buy Jacinta a new picture frame after KDD had ruined it. The book first mentions obligation when Jacinta is talking to KDD about how “the Mexican Primroses are taking over” the garden. This is what follows:“You don’t like them?”She studied my face, then smiled. “Actually, I do. They can survive anything. The others are too much trouble.”“Why don’t you pull them out?”She shrugged. “Once you take on something, you feel obligated.”A thought came to me. If I’d known the word, I’d have said it was a premonition. A hint of time when I might be too much trouble, and Miss would still feel obligated.There is a consistent thread of obligation in KDD’s involvement with Jacinta and her family. KDD makes it a point that she only signed on to be Jacinta’s Amiga for one year while she’s waiting to see if she can go back to the nightly news. Sometimes, it even seemed like KDD went out of her way to help Jacinta more because she wanted to flex her own muscles than because she actually wanted to help Jacinta’s family, probably because she got demoted from the nightly news and needed recognition to feel validated. Even when KDD decides to drive down to New Mexico to pick up Jacinta’s mom, she finds every excuse to not help: “I’m about to do a newscast! Do you know how long I’ve waited for this?...It’s too dangerous...There’s a story in the news about a guy who went to jail for driving illegals across state lines...We’ll call a lawyer tomorrow...I’ve got my boys to think about.” KDD may go out of her way to help Jacinta’s family, but it’s always out of obligation or guilt or to be seen as a hero. She never goes out of her way to learn about where Jacinta comes from. She seems to always brush off anything Jacinta tells her about her culture, which brings me to my next point.The author continually portrays Jacinta, her family, and Mexicans in general, from a deficit-based perspective. An example of this is the author’s characterization of Jacinta’s world as a “small world.” Just because Jacinta and her family don’t take gymnastics lessons at the rec center or French lessons at the community college, it doesn’t mean their world is small. Lack of access to institutions doesn’t necessarily mean their world is small. KDD (AKA JRR) fails to recognize how Jacinta’s family’s connection to Mexico makes her world much bigger than KDD’s world to begin with. KDD (AKA JRR) clearly has no idea that Jacinta actually lives between 2 worlds and is developing a much more complex understanding of these worlds. The author highlights Christmas with the Dahl family, but doesn’t talk about how beautiful Christmas can be in Jacinta’s family, or Easter, or other holidays. JRR presents one side of a stereotype of Mexicans by having KDD say “What were your parents thinking? You know what it’s like in Mexico. Drugs. Kidnappings.” JRR, however, never provides a positive or culture rich perspective of Mexicans.The way the author portrayed Jacinta’s language learning throughout the book was annoying more than anything else, so I’m not going to go into how it aligns or doesn’t align to various theories of language acquisition.Overall, I began reading this book with an open mind, but ultimately decided I'd much rather have a white lady write about her own experience mentoring "at-risk" youth than to have her write from a Mexican girl's perspective pretending to know what it feels like.
I enjoyed that the author gave insight of the true struggles the Hispanic community goes through and the affects that some of the struggles cause on families.

Jacinta is a middle school girl who lives in a small community of Mexican immigrants, many of whom are undocumented. At her youth center, she manages to get a news anchor to be her mentor. She struggles to find out who she really is, who she wants to be, and what family means to her. This book caught my attention because the protagonist is similar to the middle school students I teach, most of whom are from Mexico as first- or second-generation immigrants. I was right for the most part: this book really does speak to that often-overlooked demographic. While the author isn't Mexican herself, she writes a lot of truths about the Mexican-American experience: poverty, child-care, truancy, code shifting and vocabulary, fear of deportation, torn families, tight families, and fear of the police. It is important for kids to see themselves in the stories they read, and this book could really speak to them. As an adult reader, I had some issues. The biggest is that I didn't like any of the characters. Jacinta is not nice and is jealous of everything. She is very self-centered. Those characteristics makes her appear immature. She grows out of some of these issues at the very end, but she is largely unpleasant. Miss Kate is Jacinta's Amiga mentor, like a Big Sister. I disliked Kate even more. She doesn't seem to want to be Jacinta's Amiga and rarely seems happy to be spending time with her. At one point, she gives Jacinta and her sister Rosa purity rings so that they stay away from boys. Abstinence-only education has been proven ineffective, yet this jaded woman throws rings at the girls and tells them to stay away from boys. This sounds like the author is pushing her beliefs on the reader. At another point, when Jacinta is talking about going to Mexico, Kate says, "You know what it's like in Mexico. Drugs. Kidnappings." What the heck? Jacinta doesn't even argue with her, as if in agreement. That sounds pretty racist to me. Jacinta has a rough relationship with her "best friend" Angelica, but they are constantly awful to each other. No wonder Jacinta doesn't have any friends. Again, the "mi Amiga es mejor que tu Amiga" is something elementary-aged kids would squabble about. Jactina's transformation at the end is actually quite beautiful, and I think this story could be potentially empowering to kiddos who share similar experiences as my students have.
A simplistic view of recent immigrants in the US but I think it would be good for my students. They need more books that reflect their lives.

This is one of those instances when a disagreeable main character actually heightens my enjoyment of the story. Both Jacinta and Miss are dimensional characters with sometimes grating flaws, but both have enough shining moments of self-realization to be satisfying. It's a tough book to read in light of the struggles that Jacinta and her family face: trying to fit in while also holding onto their own culture and family; the relative privilege of any particular person when seen through another's eyes; the more contentious issues of illegal immigration and trying to better one's life.One aspect I found incredibly compelling was that these families were coming to the United States for education for their kids, but the eldest daughters were dropping out of school and becoming de facto parents because the parents were working multiple jobs, or otherwise absent. Their journey was an amazingly uphill climb and yet they did it anyway.It appears that the book is written by the equivalent of "Miss" - and I would love to hear from her two "mentees" who apparently offered at least some of their stories as fodder for this novel. The story itself is fascinating, combining the universal challenges of growing up with specific issues to the Juarez family's immigration status. But I do wonder if the story would have read differently if actually written by the immigrant instead of the "well-meaning church lady."

description: With humor and sensitivity, a debut novelist explores the coming of age of a girl caught between two cultures as she finds the courage to forge a new destiny."Miss, will you be my Amiga?" Amiga means "friend" in Spanish, but at the youth center, it meant a lady to take you places. I never asked myself if two people as different as Miss and me could ever really be amigas. When Jacinta Juarez is paired with a rich, famous mentor, she is swept away from the diapers and dishes of her own daily life into a world of new experiences. But crossing la linea into Miss’s world is scary. Half of Jacinta aches for the comfort of Mamá and the familiar safety of the barrio, while the other half longs to embrace a future that offers more than cleaning stuff for white people. When her family is torn apart, Jacinta needs to bring the two halves of herself together to win back everything she's lost. Can she channel the power she’s gained from her mentor and the strength she’s inherited from Mamá to save her shattered home life?
title: Look Both Ways in the Barrio Blanco
